"THE ART AND CRAFT OF TATTOOING\
A Hand-Book for Tattooists\
CONTENTS\

13. Master Adept\
14. Grand Master\
15. When Not To Tattoo\
16. Updates"

"INTRODUCTORY NOTES\
\
Tattooing is a method of using one's body as a means of identification and communication. Long before the crafts which require industry and materials, primitive tattoos and scars existed -- possibly the first of mankind's crafts. A tattooist may apply various symbols and decorative effects to persons -- over seventy unique symbols and designs are currently employed by the most skilled tattooists."

"RELATED CRAFTS\
\
While a tattooist works only upon living human skin, there are related crafts whose effects are similar. Jewelry, weapons and most other metal items require the services of an ENGRAVER; stationery is the specialty of the EMBOSSER; and working with clothing items is the province of the EMBROIDERER. A tattooist with skill in one or more of these auxiliary crafts will find more fortune and fame in his or her career."

"MEASURES OF PROFICIENCY\
\
Ten levels of proficiency are commonly recognized for the tattooist's skill:\
\
1. Novice\
2. Junior Apprentice\
3. Senior Apprentice\
4. Fellowcraft\
5. Journeyman\
6. Artisan\
7. Senior Artisan\
8. Master\
9. Master Adept\
10. Grand Master\
\
A Novice tattooist possesses very limited ability, and is able to attempt only a few rudimentary symbols, while a seasoned Master may command dozens of decorative options.\
\
The remainder of this hand-book describes the symbols available to tattooists at each level of proficiency."

"NOVICE\
\
Novices are the least experienced class of tattooists. Their decorative options are admittedly rather plain and utilitarian.\
\
They may apply various symbols to their patrons, such as the dot, line, mark, squiggle, smileyface, or the potato."

"JUNIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Junior Apprentices know a bit more than Novices, but their improved efforts can hardly be called impressive.\
\
The symbols which they might employ include the square, circle, triangle, heart, star, moon, sun, key, leaf, and the eye."

"SENIOR APPRENTICE\
\
Senior Apprentices have attained sufficient skill to apply a handful of modest but attractive symbols.\
\
At this level of skill, they can confidently depict a flower, dove, owl, duck, fish, hare, ermine, cat, rat, boat, kite, chair, plume, or rose."

"FELLOWCRAFT\
\
Fellowcraft tattooists have spent many hours learning their trade.\
\
They can embroider a clef, quill, mask, thistle, anchor, tankard, hourglass, tree, needle, plow, scroll, paintbrush, or a crow."

"JOURNEYMAN\
\
Journeymen possess the confidence to work with symbols of unique appeal and significance.\
\
The range of symbols they employ encompasses the sword, hammer, fist, skull, thunderbolt, serpent, dagger, scythe, and raven."

"ARTISAN\
\
Artisans are capable of the fine control needed to produce some of the more challenging and beautiful depictions of fierce beasts.\
\
Symbols they might employ are the walrus, monkey, swan, stag, lion, bull, bear, eagle, boar, wolf, horse, or fox."

"SENIOR ARTISAN\
\
Senior Artisans are sought by those desiring rare and exotic symbols etched upon their skin. They often serve as assistants to Master tattooists.\
\
They might employ the trefoil, quatrefoil, cinquefoil, caduceus, lyre, compass, palette, spinningwheel, loom, or rose-vine."

"MASTER\
\
Masters are the virtuosi of the tattooist's art. Their long career of study and craftsmanship has brought them the ability to work with complex symbols requiring great skill to execute. They can also alter a tattoo that has previously been applied (style 'none').\
\
The fierce heraldic animals -- gryphon, unicorn, wyvern, phoenix, manticore, or basilisk -- can be depicted by a Master's art."

"MASTER ADEPT\
\
Master Adepts have spent countless seasons practicing their skills, and are usually the most skilled tattooists within the Castle. They can create certain symbols of exceptional difficulty and depth of meaning -- the dragon, and the castle."

"GRAND MASTER\
\
Only rarely is there a Grand Master of the embroidery art within the Castle. When these experts appear, their creations are almost entirely at the order of the most discerning cognoscenti. Only Grand Masters may tattoo the Royal emblem of the triflame; the lesser symbol of the snowflake is also within their skill."

"WHEN NOT TO TATTOO\
\
Tattooists should emphasize to their patrons the semi-permanent effect of a tattoo; also, that these are tattoos meant to be seen. Tattoos embodying criminal messages or intent can be the subject of charges under Her Majesty's Capitulary. A tattooist should never employ his or her craft upon a person not willing, nor upon minors, nor upon persons without complete command of their faculties."

"UPDATES\
\
Tattooists, embroiderers, illustrators and other artists within the Castle are continuously creating new symbols that may be employed in their crafts. The text of this book will mysteriously update itself as new choices become available; tattooists with higher skills will inform you if and when updates occur.\
\
Please bring typographical errors or other textual problems found in this volume to the attention of the staff."
